callforshadab writes:
> $bin/arcreader -f gzipdump <path to arc file> 
> it's not doing anything, except that, initially it displays some sensible 
> charactor later on it starts displaying non- sensible characters. I also tried 
> some other software for extracting arc file. for eg: ark, etc. etc. 
> But they all show error message "unknown archive format or corrupted 
> archive" 

First, the ARC files generated by Heritrix are *NOT* ARC archives
like those generated by PKArc or other older compression
programs. Attempting to use these to read them is futile.

An ARC file contains multiple GZIP compressed chunks, separated by a
plain-text header. The gzipdump dumps these raw records, which is not
what you want. Rather you want the 'nohead' format.

The first step in dealing with an ARC file is to generate the index,
which will include the offsets of each record in the ARC file:

% $bin/arcreader -f cdx ARCPATH > ARCPATH.index

The 7th field (first numeric) is the offset in the ARC file for that
record. The 3rd field is the URL of the record.

Let's say that the offset of the entry you want is 916. To extract
that entry, use:

% $bin/arcreader -f nohead -o 916 ARCPATH > OUTFILE

> While Dealing with the arc format some queries came in to my mind.  
> 1. What is the advantage of arc file format?? 

An ARC file can store tens of thousands of small documents without
causing undue fragmentation on your disk. The format is inherently
scalable, up to the maximum file size of your operating system.

> 3. Can more than one threads read the records from the same arc file at 
> the same time. 

Depends on the reader. Once you've generated the index you can read
the entries in any order, since it is essentially a read-only format
once Heritrix is done with it.

> 4. What could be the maximum size of an arc file. 

The maximum size of a file on your OS. I don't suggest you do this. By
default its 100 MB (though if you download a single file greater than
this size, it will be written in the ARC file even beyond that max.)

> 5. How can i write my own arc reader that reads the various documents 
> from the arc file. 

The format is available online, though there isn't a reason to do
this. Java, Python, and C++ readers already exist.

> 6. What kind of format does the arc file stores. 

Anything at all: the raw octets of whatever is downloaded for a URL
are stored without any interpretation.
